triples.statement: He grew up in a 23-room mansion in the Jamaica Estates neighborhood of Queens with his older siblings, Maryanne, Fred Jr., and Elizabeth, and his younger brother, Robert.
In 1973, Roy Cohn assisted Trump in a $100 million countersuit against the U.S. government, which had accused Trump's properties of discriminating against Black applicants and tenants.
In 1979, Cohn introduced Trump to political consultant Roger Stone, whom Trump hired to handle matters with the federal government.
As of 2018, over a thirty-year period, Trump was involved in over 4,000 lawsuits and other legal filings, many of which were for nonpayment by his employees, contractors, brokers, and lawyers.
From 1991 to 2009, Trump filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for six businesses, including the Plaza Hotel, Atlantic City casinos, and the Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts company.
In 1978, Donald Trump gained public attention with his family's first Manhattan project, which was the renovation of the derelict Commodore Hotel next to Grand Central Terminal.
Trump Tower houses the headquarters of the Trump Corporation and Trump's PAC, and it served as his primary residence until 2019.
Trump bought the Plaza Hotel in 1988 with a loan from a consortium of 16 banks.
In 1992, the Plaza Hotel filed for bankruptcy protection, and a subsequent reorganization plan gave control of the property to the banks.
In 1995, after defaulting on over $3 billion in bank loans, Trump's lenders seized the Plaza Hotel and most of his other properties in a restructuring that enabled him to avoid personal bankruptcy.
An attorney for the lead bank commented on the decision, stating that the banks agreed Trump would be "better alive than dead."

In 2024, The New York Times and ProPublica reported that the IRS was investigating whether Trump had improperly written off losses twice on his Chicago tower, which he had declared worthless on his 2008 tax return.
In 1984, Donald Trump opened the Harrah's at Trump Plaza hotel and casino with assistance from the Holiday Corporation.
Both Harrah's at Trump Plaza and Trump's Castle filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1992.
The Trump Taj Mahal was financed with $675 million in junk bonds, completed for $1.1 billion, and opened in April 1990.
Under the terms of the restructuring agreement, Trump relinquished half of his initial stake and personally guaranteed future performance.
To lower his $900 million personal debt, Trump sold the Trump Shuttle airline, his megayacht the Trump Princess, and other businesses.
In 1995, Trump founded Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts (THCR), which took ownership of the Trump Plaza.
In 1996, Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts (THCR) purchased the Taj Mahal and the Trump Castle; the company went bankrupt in 2004 and 2009, reducing Trump's ownership to 10 percent.
Trump remained chairman of Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts until 2009.
In 1985, Trump acquired the Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Florida.
He declared the club his primary residence in 2019.
More than 50 licensing or management deals involving the Trump name generated at least $59 million for his companies.
The United States Football League folded after the 1985 season, largely due to Trump's attempt to move to a fall schedule and to force a merger with the NFL through an antitrust lawsuit.
In 1989 and 1990, Trump lent his name to the Tour de Trump cycling race, which was an attempt to create an American version of European races like the Tour de France or the Giro d'Italia.

From 1986 to 1988, Trump bought large blocks of shares in public companies, suggested he would take them over, and then sold the shares for a profit, leading some to believe he was engaging in greenmail.
The New York Times reported that while Trump initially made millions from these stock transactions, he lost most or all of the gains after investors stopped taking his takeover suggestions seriously.
In 1988, Trump purchased the Eastern Air Lines Shuttle with $380 million in loans from a syndicate of 22 banks.
He renamed the airline Trump Shuttle and operated it until 1992.
In 1991, Trump defaulted on his loans, and ownership of the airline passed to the banks.
In 2002, he moved both pageants to NBC due to scheduling disagreements with CBS.
Shortly after winning the 2016 presidential election, Trump agreed to pay $25 million to settle the three cases.
The Donald J. Trump Foundation was a private foundation established in 1988.
After donating $65,000 in 2007–2008, Trump stopped making personal donations to the charity, which subsequently received millions from other donors, including $5 million from Vince McMahon.
The foundation donated to health and sports-related charities, conservative groups, and charities that held events at Trump properties.
In 2016, The Washington Post reported that the charity had committed potential legal and ethical violations, including self-dealing and tax evasion.

In 2016, the New York attorney general ordered the foundation to immediately cease fundraising in New York, stating it had violated state law by soliciting donations without the required annual external audits.
In December 2016, Trump's team announced that the foundation would be dissolved.
The New York attorney general's office filed a civil suit in June 2018 against the foundation, Trump, and his adult children, seeking $2.8 million in restitution and other penalties.
The foundation ceased its operations in December 2018 and gave its assets to other charities.
A 2018 review by USA Today found that Donald Trump and his businesses had been involved in over 4,000 state and federal legal actions.
Although he has not filed for personal bankruptcy, Donald Trump's hotel and casino businesses filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection six times between 1991 and 2009.
The businesses continued to operate while banks restructured debt and reduced his shares in the properties.
Following his corporate bankruptcies in the early 1990s, most major banks, with the exception of Deutsche Bank, declined to lend to him.
After the January 6 Capitol attack, Deutsche Bank decided it would no longer do business with Donald Trump or his affiliated company.
Donald Trump has claimed he started his career with a "small loan of a million dollars" from his father, which he had to repay with interest.
In 1984, posing as a Trump Organization official named "John Barron," Donald Trump called journalist Jonathan Greenberg to try to get a higher ranking on the Forbes 400 list of wealthy Americans.
In 2015, Forbes estimated Donald Trump's net worth at $4.5 billion, based on interviews with more than 80 sources.
In 2025, Forbes estimated Donald Trump's net worth at $5.1 billion and ranked him the 700th wealthiest person in the world.
Donald Trump has published 19 books under his name, most of which were written or co-written by ghostwriters.
Donald Trump's first book, "The Art of the Deal" (1987), was a New York Times Best Seller and was credited by The New Yorker with making him famous as an "emblem of the successful tycoon."
From 2004 to 2008, Donald Trump had his own short-form talk radio program called "Trumped!".
In 2021, Donald Trump, a member since 1989, resigned from SAG-AFTRA to avoid a disciplinary hearing regarding the January 6 attack.
Two days after his resignation, SAG-AFTRA permanently barred Donald Trump.
The New York Times described his portrayal as "a highly flattering, highly fictionalized version" of himself.
The shows remade Trump's image for millions of viewers nationwide.
The shows and related licensing agreements earned Trump more than $400 million.
Trump was a candidate in the 2000 Reform Party presidential primaries for three months before withdrawing in February 2000.
In February 2011, he spoke at the Conservative Political Action Conference and gave speeches in states with early primaries.
In May 2011, Trump announced he would not run for president.
Donald Trump announced his candidacy for the 2016 election in June 2015.
His campaign statements were frequently opaque and suggestive, with a record number being false.
Trump advocated for increased military spending and extreme vetting or a ban on immigrants from Muslim-majority countries.
He promised to build a wall on the Mexico–U.S. border and stated that Mexico would pay for it.
His campaign launch speech was criticized for claiming Mexican immigrants were "bringing drugs, they're bringing crime, they're rapists," which led to NBC firing him from Celebrity Apprentice.
Contrary to the practice of major candidates since 1976 and his own promises, Trump did not release his tax returns.

Following a long court battle and two Supreme Court appeals by Trump, the high court in February 2021 permitted his tax returns and other records to be released to the Manhattan district attorney for a grand jury review.
Trump was the only president who had not served in the military or held any prior government office.
Trump's victory led to protests in major U.S. cities.
The day after his inauguration, an estimated 2.6 million people worldwide, including 500,000 in Washington, D.C., protested against him in the Women's Marches.

During his first week in office, Trump signed six executive orders, which included authorizing the repeal of the Affordable Care Act, withdrawing from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, advancing the Keystone XL and Dakota Access Pipeline projects, and planning a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border.

Before his inauguration, Donald Trump placed his businesses into a revocable trust rather than a blind trust or a similar arrangement that would have completely severed him from his business interests.
Trump continued to profit from his businesses and was aware of how his administration's policies impacted them.
Despite pledging to avoid "new foreign deals," the Trump Organization pursued operational expansions in Scotland, Dubai, and the Dominican Republic.
One of the emoluments cases was dismissed in a lower court.
Two emoluments cases were dismissed by the Supreme Court as moot after Trump's term ended.
During his campaign, Trump pledged to donate his presidential salary and profits from foreign patronage to the U.S. government.

In 2024, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington reported that Trump had donated $448,000 of an estimated $13.6 million he received in payments from foreign governments during his first term.
The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 reduced tax rates for businesses and individuals and eliminated the penalty for the Affordable Care Act's individual mandate.
By the end of his term, the U.S. national debt had increased by 39 percent to $27.75 trillion, and the debt-to-GDP ratio reached a post-World War II high.
Trump did not deliver on his campaign promise of a $1 trillion infrastructure spending plan.
He rejects the scientific consensus on climate change.
Trump reduced the budget for renewable energy research by 40 percent and reversed Obama-era policies aimed at curbing climate change.
He aimed to increase the production and exports of fossil fuels.

He weakened animal protections and environmental standards for federal infrastructure projects, and he expanded areas permitted for drilling and resource extraction, including allowing drilling in the Arctic Refuge.

Trump dismantled federal regulations concerning health, labor, the environment, and other areas, which included a bill revoking an Obama-era rule that restricted firearm sales to severely mentally ill individuals.
In his first six weeks in office, Trump delayed, suspended, or reversed ninety federal regulations, often following requests from the regulated industries.
The Institute for Policy Integrity found that 78 percent of his proposals were either blocked by courts or did not succeed in litigation.
During his campaign, Trump vowed to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.

In June 2018, the Trump administration joined 18 Republican-led states to argue before the Supreme Court that the Affordable Care Act was unconstitutional because the financial penalties for the individual mandate had been eliminated.
This legal challenge, which was unsuccessful, would have eliminated health insurance coverage for up to 23 million Americans.
In January 2020, he indicated a willingness to consider cuts to Medicare and other social safety-net programs.
In response to the opioid epidemic, Trump signed legislation in 2018 to increase funding for drug treatments but was widely criticized for not creating a concrete strategy.
He stated his support for "traditional marriage" but considered the nationwide legality of same-sex marriage to be "settled."
His administration rolled back key elements of the Obama administration's workplace protections against discrimination of LGBTQ people.

An attempted rollback of anti-discrimination protections for transgender patients in August 2020 was stopped by a federal judge following a Supreme Court ruling that extended employee civil rights protections to gender identity and sexual orientation.
Trump has stated he is opposed to gun control, though his views have changed over time.
In 2016, he said he supported using interrogation torture methods that were "a hell of a lot worse than waterboarding."
In a January 2018 discussion about immigration legislation, Trump reportedly referred to El Salvador, Haiti, Honduras, and African nations as "shithole countries."
His remarks were condemned as racist.
In July 2019, Trump tweeted that four Democratic congresswomen, all of whom are minorities and three of whom are native-born, should "go back" to the countries they "came from."
Two days later, the House of Representatives voted 240–187, largely along party lines, to condemn his "racist comments."
White nationalist publications and social media praised his remarks, which he continued to make over the following days.
Many retired military leaders and defense officials condemned his proposal to use the U.S. military against anti-police-brutality protesters.
During his first term, Trump granted 237 requests for clemency, a number lower than all presidents since 1900 except for George H. W. Bush and George W. Bush.
On his last full day in office, Trump granted 73 pardons and commuted 70 sentences.
Several of Trump's allies were not eligible for pardons under Justice Department rules, and in some cases, the department had opposed clemency.
Military leaders opposed the pardons of three military service members who were convicted of or charged with violent crimes.
Trump reduced the number of admitted refugees to record lows, lowering the annual limit from 110,000 before his presidency to 15,000 in 2021.
A central campaign promise was building a wall on the U.S.–Mexico border; during his first term, 73 miles of new wall were built and 365 miles of older barriers were replaced.
In 2018, Trump's refusal to sign a spending bill without border wall funding led to the longest federal government shutdown in U.S. history, lasting 35 days from December 2018 to January 2019.
The government shutdown ended when Trump agreed to fund the government without money for the wall.
In February, to prevent another shutdown, Congress passed a funding bill that included $1.4 billion for border fencing.
In September, Trump replaced the ban with a proclamation that extended travel restrictions to North Koreans, Chadians, and some Venezuelan officials, while removing Iraq and Sudan.
The Supreme Court permitted this version of the ban to take effect in December 2017 and ultimately upheld it in 2019.
As of April 2024, 1,360 children had not been confirmed as having been reunified with their families.
Trump described himself as a "nationalist" and his foreign policy as "America First".
He supported populist, neo-nationalist, and authoritarian governments.
Trump supported many of the policies of Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
In 2020, Trump hosted the signing of the Abraham Accords between Israel and the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain to normalize their foreign relations.
In 2018, Trump began a trade war with China by imposing tariffs and other trade barriers, which he said would compel China to end unfair trade practices and intellectual property infringement.
Trump weakened the toughest U.S. sanctions that were imposed after the 2014 Russian annexation of Crimea.
Trump praised and, according to some critics, rarely criticized Russian president Vladimir Putin, though he opposed some actions of Russia's government.
Talks in October 2019 broke down and no denuclearization agreement was reached.
By the end of Trump's first year in office, 34 percent of his original staff had resigned, been fired, or been reassigned.
By July 2018, 61 percent of Trump's senior aides had left, and 141 staffers had left in the previous year.
Both staff turnover figures set a record for recent presidents.
Close personal aides to Trump quit or were forced out.
Trump publicly disparaged several of his former top officials.
Trump had four White House chiefs of staff, marginalizing or pushing out several.
Three of Trump's 15 original cabinet members left or were forced to resign within his first year.
In October 2017, there were hundreds of sub-cabinet positions without a nominee.
By January 8, 2019, of 706 key positions, 433 had been filled and there was no nominee for 264.
Donald Trump appointed 226 federal judges, including 54 to the courts of appeals and three to the Supreme Court: Neil Gorsuch, Brett Kavanaugh, and Amy Coney Barrett.
His Supreme Court appointments politically shifted the Court to the right.
Trump later took credit when Roe v. Wade was overturned by Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization in 2022, a case in which all three of his Supreme Court nominees voted with the majority.
On January 29, Trump established the White House Coronavirus Task Force.
On March 27, Trump signed the CARES Act, a $2.2 trillion bipartisan economic stimulus bill that was the largest in U.S. history.
In April, after weeks of attacks to divert attention from his slow response, Trump halted funding for the World Health Organization.

In April 2020, Republican-connected groups organized anti-lockdown protests against state government measures, and Trump encouraged these protests on Twitter, even though the targeted states did not meet his administration's reopening guidelines.
Donald Trump was the subject of ten federal criminal investigations, eight state and local investigations, and twelve congressional investigations.
In July 2016, the FBI initiated an investigation named Crossfire Hurricane to examine potential links between Russia and Donald Trump's 2016 campaign.
After Donald Trump fired James Comey in May 2017, the FBI began a second investigation into Trump's personal and business dealings with Russia.
At the request of Rod Rosenstein, the Mueller investigation examined criminal matters related to Russia's interference in the 2016 election.
Robert Mueller submitted his final report in March 2019.
Donald Trump claimed the report exonerated him, even though Robert Mueller wrote that it did not.
Donald Trump sued the banks, Mazars, and committee chair Elijah Cummings to block the disclosures.
In September 2022, Donald Trump and the committee reached a settlement concerning Mazars, and the firm started to provide the documents.

Trump's first impeachment arose from a whistleblower complaint that in July 2019 he pressured Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy to investigate Joe and Hunter Biden to gain an advantage in the 2020 presidential election.
Seven Republican senators voted for conviction.
Donald Trump filed to run for reelection just hours after becoming president in 2017.
Less than a month after taking office, Trump held his first reelection rally, and he officially became the Republican nominee in August 2020.
Trump's campaign focused on crime, asserting that cities would become lawless if Democratic nominee Joe Biden won.
He repeatedly misrepresented Biden's positions and appealed to racism.
Beginning in early 2020, Trump cast doubt on the election, claiming without evidence that it would be rigged and that extensive mail-in voting would result in massive fraud.

section_path: Loss to Biden and rejection of outcome

triples.statement: In the November 2020 election, Joe Biden received 81.3 million votes to Donald Trump's 74.2 million, and 306 electoral votes to Trump's 232, with the Electoral College formalizing the victory on December 14.
On the morning after the election, Trump declared victory before the results were known.
When Biden was projected as the winner days later, Trump made baseless allegations of election fraud.
Trump initially blocked government officials from cooperating in Biden's presidential transition.
After three weeks, the General Services Administration administrator declared Biden the "apparent winner," which allowed the disbursement of transition resources to his team.
Trump did not attend Biden's inauguration on January 20.
In December 2020, reports indicated that U.S. military leaders were on high alert and had discussed how to respond if Trump declared martial law.
CIA director Gina Haspel and Army general Mark Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, became concerned that Trump might attempt a coup or military action against China or Iran.
Trump's supporters then formed a mob that broke into the Capitol building, which disrupted the certification process and led to the evacuation of Congress.
In a tweet at 6 p.m., Trump told the rioters to "go home with love & in peace," called them "great patriots," and reiterated that he had won the election.
Congress later reconvened and confirmed Biden's victory in the early hours of January 7.
Over 140 police officers were injured, and five people died during or after the attack.
After leaving the White House, Donald Trump began living at Mar-a-Lago, where he established an office under the provisions of the Former Presidents Act.
Trump's ongoing false claims about the 2020 election were termed the "big lie" by his critics, though in May 2021, he and his supporters started using the phrase to describe the election itself.
Trump continued to pressure state legislators to overturn the election.
Unlike other former presidents, Trump maintained his dominance over his party, with a 2022 New York Times profile describing him as a modern party boss.
A significant part of his focus was on party governance and appointing loyal officials to key positions.
In the 2022 midterm elections, Trump endorsed over 200 candidates for various offices.
In February 2021, Trump registered a new company, Trump Media & Technology Group (TMTG), to provide "social networking services" to U.S. customers.
In March 2024, TMTG merged with the special-purpose acquisition company Digital World Acquisition and became a public company.
In February 2022, TMTG launched Truth Social, a social media platform.
In 2019, journalist E. Jean Carroll accused Trump of a rape in the 1990s and sued him for defamation over his denial.
In 2022, Carroll sued Trump again for battery and further defamation.
In 2022, New York filed a civil lawsuit against Trump, accusing him of inflating the value of the Trump Organization to gain advantages with lenders and banks.
Trump was found liable and ordered to pay nearly $355 million plus interest.
In August 2025, an appeals court upheld Trump's liability and nonmonetary penalties but voided the monetary penalty as excessive.

In December 2022, the U.S. House committee on the January 6 attack recommended criminal charges against Trump for obstructing an official proceeding, conspiracy to defraud the United States, and inciting or assisting an insurrection.
A grand jury in Fulton County, Georgia, indicted Trump in August 2023 on 13 charges, including racketeering, for his efforts to subvert the 2020 election in the state.
The case was dismissed in November 2025 after the new prosecutor declined to pursue the charges.
In January 2022, the National Archives and Records Administration retrieved 15 boxes of documents, some of which were classified, that Trump had taken to Mar-a-Lago after leaving the White House.
In the subsequent Justice Department investigation, officials retrieved more classified documents from Trump's lawyers.
Trump pleaded not guilty.
In July 2024, judge Aileen Cannon dismissed the case, ruling that special prosecutor Jack Smith's appointment was unconstitutional.
In May 2024, Trump was convicted on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.
On January 10, 2025, the judge issued a no-penalty sentence known as an unconditional discharge, stating that punitive measures would have conflicted with presidential immunity.
In November 2022, Donald Trump announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election and created a fundraising account.
By March 2024, his campaign had paid $100 million towards his legal bills.
During the campaign, Trump made increasingly violent and authoritarian statements.
Trump stated he would weaponize the FBI and the Justice Department against his political opponents and use the military to target Democratic politicians and those who did not support his candidacy.
He used harsher and more dehumanizing anti-immigrant rhetoric than during his presidency.

His rhetoric, calling his political opponents "the enemy", vermin, and fascists, has been described by some historians and scholars as authoritarian, fascist, and unlike anything a political candidate has ever said in American history.
Age and health concerns also arose during the campaign, with several medical experts highlighting an increase in rambling, tangential speech and behavioral disinhibition.
Trump mentioned "rigged election" and "election interference" earlier and more frequently than in the 2016 and 2020 campaigns and refused to commit to accepting the 2024 election results.

Analysts for The New York Times described this as an intensification of his "heads I win; tails you cheated" rhetorical strategy; the newspaper stated that the claim of a rigged election had become the backbone of the campaign.
Trump won the election in November 2024 with 312 electoral votes to incumbent vice president Kamala Harris's 226.
He also won the popular vote with 49.8% to Harris's 48.3%.
Several outlets described his reelection as an extraordinary comeback.
Trump's second term began upon his inauguration on January 20, 2025.
He became the oldest individual to assume the presidency, the first president with a felony conviction, and the second person to serve two nonconsecutive terms as president.
His attempts to expand presidential power and his conflict with the courts have been described as a defining characteristic of his second term.
Four days into his second term, a Time magazine analysis found that nearly two-thirds of his executive actions mirrored or partially mirrored proposals from Project 2025.
According to American legal scholars, several of Trump's actions in his first weeks ignored or violated federal laws, regulations, and the Constitution.
By mid-November, of the lawsuits against his actions, 149 had been blocked or partially blocked, 102 were left in effect, and 107 were pending.
Following legal setbacks, Trump increased his criticism of the judiciary and called for the impeachment of federal judges who ruled against him.

A Washington Post analysis by mid-July found that Trump defied judges and courts in about one-third of all cases against him, actions that legal experts described as unprecedented for a presidential administration.

Multiple analyses by academic scholars and The New York Times found that both Republican and Democratic judicial appointees identified numerous constitutional and statutory flaws in Trump administration policies.
Donald Trump's second presidency was described as having fewer protections against conflicts of interest than his first and as breaking with decades of ethical norms.
He maintained a publicly traded company, Trump Media & Technology Group, and diversified it into financial services.
He pursued new overseas real estate deals with state-affiliated entities and had multiple branding and licensing deals for Trump-branded merchandise.
Unlike previous presidents, he profited from events at his hotels and golf courses and did not place his assets in a blind trust.
Trump launched, promoted, and personally benefited from two cryptocurrency tokens, $Trump and $Melania.
He also directly benefited from his family's cryptocurrency company, World Liberty Financial, which was involved in an unprecedented mix of private business and government policy.
The aircraft is set to serve as Air Force One until the end of his second term, after which it will be transferred to his presidential library.
The estimated cost to retrofit the aircraft as Air Force One is up to $1 billion.
He began mass terminations of federal employees, which legal experts deemed unprecedented or illegal, with the goal of replacing them with workers who were more aligned with his agenda.
By late February, the administration had fired over 30,000 people.

To enable more terminations, the administration adopted a new legal interpretation that greatly expands which departments are considered national security agencies and declared several federal workers' unions "hostile."

Trump ordered the termination of diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) projects in the federal government and revoked Lyndon B. Johnson's 1965 Executive Order 11246, which required federal contractors to use affirmative action to stop racial discrimination.
Federal courts paused certain actions, including efforts to dismantle the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
Many of his actions were an attempt to place historically independent institutions under the direct control of the executive branch in reduced forms.
Trump threatened, signed executive actions, and ordered investigations into his political opponents, critics, and organizations aligned with the Democratic Party.
By July 2025, Trump had obtained over $1.2 billion in settlements from a "cultural crackdown" against various institutions that mostly chose to settle instead of fighting back.

Donald Trump's pardons and clemency grants favored political allies and loyalists, and disproportionately benefited powerful, famous, well-connected, and wealthy individuals accused of white-collar crimes.

On his first day in office, Trump granted clemency to all January 6 rioters who were convicted or charged, including those who violently attacked police, by pardoning over 1,500 individuals and commuting the sentences of 14 others.
Trump inherited a resilient economy from the Biden administration, which featured increasing economic growth, low unemployment, and declining inflation.
Trump ordered agencies to cease enforcement of certain rules in a large-scale deregulation effort that legal experts considered illegal and in violation of federal law.
The "Make America Healthy Again" agenda of the Trump administration promoted anti-science and anti-vaccine activism, which led to a resurgence of whooping cough and measles.

Trump promoted climate change denial and misinformation, appointed industry lobbyists to the EPA to reverse regulations, and by October 2025 had canceled $7.6 billion in funding for clean energy projects.
Trump used declarations of national emergencies to justify hundreds of actions, thereby bypassing congressional approval or regulatory review.
For example, Trump declared a national energy emergency, which permitted the suspension of environmental regulations, eased rules for fossil fuel extraction, and limited renewable energy projects.
Trump blamed societal problems on diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives and "wokeness."
Equating diversity with incompetence, he reversed pro-diversity policies within the federal government.
Trump increased the domestic use of the military, ordered deployments to several cities led by the Democratic Party, and threatened to expand these deployments.

Through executive orders and other actions, Trump banned transgender people from the military, restricted or defunded gender-affirming healthcare, opposed inclusive language, censored research and educational materials, targeted institutions for promoting "gender ideology," barred transgender athletes from sports, and required U.S. passports to state a person's sex assigned at birth.
Trump resumed the "remain in Mexico" policy, designated drug cartels as terrorist groups, and ordered the resumption of border wall construction.
Trump revoked the parole status of immigrants who entered the U.S. using CBP One and terminated humanitarian parole for Cubans, Haitians, and Nicaraguans.
In March, Trump used the Alien Enemies Act of 1798 to imprison illegal immigrants without trial at the Terrorism Confinement Center in El Salvador.
Several American citizens were detained and deported.
The Trump administration favored hard power for its "America First" foreign policy and dismantled or withdrew support from organizations that advance American soft power.
Working with the Biden administration, Trump and his incoming administration helped broker a Gaza war ceasefire that was enacted the day before his inauguration.
Israel broke the ceasefire in March.
As part of the first phase of Trump's initiative to end the Gaza war, Israel and Hamas signed an agreement on October 9, 2025, to cease fire and exchange hostages for prisoners.
Trump initiated a global trade war, imposing tariffs at the highest level since the 1930 Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act.
Economists argued that the Trump administration used flawed assumptions and misunderstood the relationship between trade deficits and tariffs.
In February 2025, the White House stated that Elon Musk was a special government employee.
Trump gave Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) access to many federal government agencies.

In the administration's first month, Elon Musk's teams operated in eighteen departments and agencies, including the Treasury Department's $5 trillion payment system, the Small Business Administration, the Office of Personnel Management, and the General Services Administration.
Starting with his 2016 campaign, Donald Trump's political style and rhetoric resulted in the formation of a political movement called Trumpism.
Trump has been described as embracing far-right extremism and helping to bring far-right fringe ideas and groups into the mainstream.
His rhetoric has been characterized as using fearmongering and demagogy, which increased during his 2024 presidential campaign.
Trump has stated his belief that real power is derived from fear.
Many of Donald Trump's comments and actions have been characterized as racist.
According to a 2018 national poll, about half of respondents said Donald Trump is racist, and a larger proportion believed he emboldened racists.
Several studies and surveys concluded that racist attitudes were a more significant factor than economic issues in fueling Donald Trump's political ascent and determining voter allegiance.
Donald Trump has been accused of racism for maintaining that five black and Latino teenagers were guilty in the 1989 Central Park jogger case, even after their 2002 exoneration.
In 2011, Donald Trump became the leading proponent of the "birther" conspiracy theory, which falsely claimed that Barack Obama was not born in the United States.
Donald Trump claimed credit for pressuring the government to release Barack Obama's birth certificate, which he then deemed fraudulent.
In September 2016, Donald Trump acknowledged that Barack Obama was born in the U.S., but he reportedly expressed birther views privately in 2017.
During his 2024 presidential campaign, Donald Trump made false attacks on the racial identity of Kamala Harris, which were compared to the birther conspiracy theory.
Donald Trump's 2024 campaign extensively used dehumanizing language and racial stereotypes.
In 2025, Donald Trump promoted false claims of white genocide in South Africa and established the White South African refugee program.
Donald Trump made lewd comments, disparaged the physical appearances of women, and used derogatory epithets to refer to them.
Donald Trump has denied the allegations of sexual misconduct.

In October 2016, a 2005 recording was released in which Donald Trump bragged about kissing and groping women without consent, stating, "when you're a star, they let you do it. You can do anything. ... Grab 'em by the pussy."
He characterized his comments about groping women as "locker-room talk".
Widespread media exposure of the incident led to Donald Trump's first public apology, which was videotaped during his 2016 presidential campaign.

section_path: Link to violence and hate crimes

triples.statement: During his 2016 campaign, Donald Trump encouraged or praised physical attacks on protesters or reporters.

A May 2020 ABC News review identified at least 54 criminal cases between August 2015 and April 2020 where Donald Trump was invoked in connection with violence or threats, mostly by white men against minorities.
After the 2020 presidential election, Donald Trump promoted conspiracy theories for his defeat that were characterized as "the big lie".
Fact-checkers from The Washington Post, the Toronto Star, and CNN compiled data on Donald Trump's "false or misleading claims" and "false claims".
Other misinformation from Donald Trump, such as misattributing a rise in crime in England and Wales to the "spread of radical Islamic terror," served his domestic political purposes.
Donald Trump habitually does not apologize for his falsehoods.
Trump posted frequently during his 2016 campaign and presidency until Twitter banned him after the January 6 attack.
During his 2024 campaign and second presidency, Trump frequently posted AI-generated content depicting himself as pop-culture icons or mocking immigrants.
Following years of criticism for permitting Trump to post misinformation, Twitter started adding fact-check tags to some of his tweets in May 2020.
After acquiring Twitter, Elon Musk reinstated Trump's account in November 2022.
In January 2023, the two-year ban from Meta Platforms expired, which allowed Trump to return to Facebook and Instagram.
Throughout his career, Donald Trump sought media attention and had a 'love-hate' relationship with the press.
All of the defamation lawsuits were dismissed.

By 2024, Trump had repeatedly supported outlawing political dissent and criticism, suggested reporters be prosecuted for not revealing confidential sources, and proposed that media companies could lose broadcast licenses for unfavorable coverage.

During his second term, Trump's actions against the media were considered unprecedented in modern U.S. history, with historians comparing them to authoritarian tactics for censoring opponents and harming freedom of speech and the press.

Trump initiated lawsuits and blacklists against some media outlets, assumed control of the process for granting access from the White House Correspondents' Association, and restricted access for all wire services.
The Federal Communications Commission initiated investigations into media outlets that were accused of being biased against Trump.
Due to Trump's threats, media executives directed journalists to self-censor and lessen criticism of him, and CBS established an Ombudsman to monitor its news channels for bias.
Trump and Ivana divorced in 1990, following his affair with model and actress Marla Maples.
